articles.headline: Trump Purge Set to Force Out More Top Homeland Security Officials
articles.snippet: As the president expressed frustration with his own administration, the top echelon of the department managing border security and other matters was being hollowed out.
articles.abstract: As the president expressed frustration with his own administration, the top echelon of the department managing border security and other matters was being hollowed out.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump moved to clear out the senior ranks of the Department of Homeland Security on Monday, a day after  forcing the resignation of its secretary, Kirstjen Nielsen, as he accelerated a purge of the nation’s immigration and security leadership.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker, Maggie Haberman, Nicholas Fandos and Zolan Kanno-Youngs

articles.headline: Trump Signals Even Fiercer Immigration Agenda, With a Possible Return of Family Separations
articles.snippet: The longer-term effect of the eruption of Oval Office frustration is likely to be a burst of anti-immigrant policies that stand out, even for Mr. Trump.
articles.abstract: The longer-term effect of the eruption of Oval Office frustration is likely to be a burst of anti-immigrant policies that stand out, even for Mr. Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s purge of the nation’s top homeland security officials is a sign that he is preparing to unleash an even fiercer assault on immigration, including a possible return of his controversial decision last summer to separate migrant children from their parents, current and former administration officials said Monday.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Demand for Saudi Aramco Bonds Sails Past the Goal
articles.snippet: Despite concerns about the company’s ties to Saudi Arabia and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, Aramco is the world’s most profitable company, and investors want a piece of it.
articles.abstract: Despite concerns about the company’s ties to Saudi Arabia and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, Aramco is the world’s most profitable company, and investors want a piece of it.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — When executives from Saudi Aramco, the giant oil company in Saudi Arabia, pitched prospective investors on the company’s first international bond offering last week, they were shown the red carpet everywhere.
articles.byline: By Stanley Reed and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Boeing’s 737 Max: 1960s Design, 1990s Computing Power and Paper Manuals
articles.snippet: The Boeing jet that crashed twice in five months relied on decades-old systems and left pilots without some common safety features.
articles.abstract: The Boeing jet that crashed twice in five months relied on decades-old systems and left pilots without some common safety features.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pilots start some new Boeing planes by turning a knob and flipping two switches.
articles.byline: By Jack Nicas and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: In Trump, Netanyahu Sees an Ally Who Helps Him Push the Envelope
articles.snippet: President Trump has given Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu the political cover to embrace a position that critics say would all but extinguish the dream of a viable Palestinian state.
articles.abstract: President Trump has given Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu the political cover to embrace a position that critics say would all but extinguish the dream of a viable Palestinian state.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s vow for Israel to annex parts of the West Bank would flout four decades of American policy, under both Republican and Democratic presidents. But nothing emboldened Mr. Netanyahu to take such a risk more than the support of his ally President Trump.

articles.headline: At Trump’s Florida Resort Empire, a Quiet Effort to Eliminate an Undocumented Work Force
articles.snippet: A large immigrant work force helps run Mr. Trump’s resorts, an embarrassing reality for a president who has railed against undocumented migrants.
articles.abstract: A large immigrant work force helps run Mr. Trump’s resorts, an embarrassing reality for a president who has railed against undocumented migrants.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH, Fla. — Behind the clipped hedges of President Trump’s sumptuous private clubs in South Florida, including his Mar-a-Lago estate where he has spent many getaway weekends, there has long been a built-in contradiction to the policy the president has repeatedly described as “America First.”
articles.byline: By Miriam Jordan, Annie Correal and Patricia Mazzei

articles.headline: U.S. Readies $11 Billion in Tariffs on E.U.
articles.snippet: The U.S. and Europe said they are preparing to impose tit-for-tat tariffs as part of a long dispute over aerospace subsidies.
articles.abstract: The U.S. and Europe said they are preparing to impose tit-for-tat tariffs as part of a long dispute over aerospace subsidies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States and the European Union are preparing to impose tit-for-tat tariffs on each other’s products, the latest escalation in a 14-year fight over government aid given to Boeing and European rival Airbus.

articles.headline: Bank of America Will Lift Minimum Wage to $20, as Lawmakers Spotlight Inequality
articles.snippet: A day before he was to testify before Congress, the chief executive, Brian Moynihan, said the lowest-paid workers would earn $17 an hour starting in May and $20 in two years.
articles.abstract: A day before he was to testify before Congress, the chief executive, Brian Moynihan, said the lowest-paid workers would earn $17 an hour starting in May and $20 in two years.
articles.lead_paragraph: A day before he was to appear at a congressional hearing focused on the biggest banks in the United States, Bank of America’s chief executive, Brian Moynihan, said on Tuesday that the bank planned to raise its minimum wage to $20 an hour from $15 over the next two years.
